message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.FileReader;
import java.util.StringTokenizer;

public class ReadFile {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            String csvFile = "Data.txt";
            // create BufferedReader to read csv file
            BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(csvFile));
            String line = "";
            StringTokenizer st = null;
            int lineNumber = 0;

            // read comma separated file line by line
            while ((line = br.readLine()) != null) {
                lineNumber++;
                // use comma as token separator
                st = new StringTokenizer(line, "=");
                while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
                    String token = st.nextToken().trim();
                    if (token.equals("NoScans") || token.equals("NoPixels") || token.equals("ProdULLat")
                            || token.equals("ProdULLon") || token.equals("ProdLRLat") || token.equals("ProdLRLon")) {
                        // display selected tokens
                        System.out.print(st.nextToken().trim() + "  ");
                    } else {
                        // skip tokens
                        st.nextToken();
                    }
                }
                System.out.println();
            }
            br.close();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            System.err.println("CSV file cannot be read : " + e);
        }
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: In the given code, I have modified the token separator from "," to "=" as per the format of the file. Then, I have added a condition to check if the token is one of the selected fields (NoScans, NoPixels, ProdULLat, ProdULLon, ProdLRLat, ProdLRLon). If it is, I display the next token as the corresponding value. If it is not, I skip the next token. This way, only the selected fields and their values are displayed in the output.
